case_data.summary:
Background

Generally speaking, F-1 visas (colloquially "student visas") can be granted to international students who attend American universities. However, regulations on the granting of these visas limit the amount of online or distance learning the student can engage in. According to these regulations, an international student can engage in only one such class or three credits of that class per semester. 8 C.F.R. § 214.2(f)(6)(i)(G).

The COVID-19 outbreak in early 2020 made this regulation untenable, as schools and universities had to shift to online learning systems. In response, defendant ICE issued an exemption on March 13, 2020, affirming that international students would be permitted to continue distance learning in the United States under their F-1 visas. The exemption would apply until the end of the emergency. However, on July 6, 2020, ICE issued a new directive stating that it would rescind that exemption. This directive would then mean that international students at schools that would still be fully online would have to either transfer to other schools that were at least partially in-person, go back to their countries voluntarily, or risk deportation. The directive also ordered schools that had gone fully online or had simply decided not to have classes to submit an "operational change plan" within nine days, and ordered schools that would have a hybrid system to certify each F-1 student to make sure that they were not taking entirely online courses.

The Lawsuit

This lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California on July 10, 2020, four days after the directive was issued. Plaintiffs were seven foreign nationals attending University of California schools at the post-graduate level. They were represented by Public Counsel and private attorneys. Defendants were the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The plaintiffs claimed that the new directive violated the Administrative Procedure Act in four ways: 1) the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to consider reliance interests of F-1 and M-1 visa holders; 2) the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to offer a reasoned basis to justify the policy; 3) defendants did not engage in notice-and-comment rulemaking when coming up with the new policy; and 4) the directive violated the Fifth Amendment in that it stripped plaintiffs of their visas without due process of law. Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief in the form of a temporary restraining order as well as preliminary and permanent injunctions prohibiting the agencies from enforcing the new directive. Plaintiffs also requested that the court vacate and set aside the new directive, in addition to declaratory relief and attorney's fees and costs. The case was assigned to Judge Cormac J. Carney and Magistrate Judge Karen E. Scott.

The students filed an application for a temporary restraining order on July 14.

Meanwhile, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same directive, President and Fellows of Harvard College, the parties conferred and the defendants agreed to rescind their implementation of the directive and to return to the March policy.

On July 16, the parties filed a joint stipulation that stated the government agreed to rescind the July directive by removing it from its website and replacing it with the March guidance, which mooted the students original claims. However, in an amendment to the students' application for a temporary restraining order, they noted that despite the removal, the government failed to issue a formal statement of rescission or explanation and failed to issue a statement confirming that the March guidance would remain in effect for the duration of the emergency. They sought an order directing the government to administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency.

The government filed a motion to dismiss and opposition to the students' application for a temporary restraining order. On August 3, the court denied the students' application for a temporary restraining order because the rescission satisfied much of the relief demanded by plaintiffs. The court also denied the government's motion to dismiss, allowing the students to amend their complaint to clarify the relief they continued to seek.

The students filed an amended complaint on August 14. The complaint reiterated their demands from the amended application for a temporary restraining order. They sought a declaration that the July 6 directive was improperly issued in violation of the APA and the plaintiffs' due process rights and a directive that the government administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency. The government filed a motion to dismiss on August 28.

The court found that the students' claims were moot and granted the government's motion to dismiss on October 1, 2020.
case_data.summary_short:
Seven unnamed individuals sued ICE and DHS over their new directive that would effectively force international students to take in-person classes or risk deportation. The suit alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Due Process Clause. Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief prohibiting the enforcement of the directive and an order vacating the directive. 

On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded. In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance, but the plaintiffs in this case filed an amended complaint that sought a formal declaration that the July 6 directive was improperly issued and an order that the government administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency. The court found that the students' claims were mooted by the rescission and granted the government's motion to dismiss on October 1, 2020.
case_data.summary_tiny: Yet another case suing @ICEgov and @DHSgov following the July 6 directive that would all force international students to take in-person classes or face deportation. This time it's 7 private plaintiffs repped by @PublicCounsel and @SidleyLaw

1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  Less than one month after the Supreme Court held that the Executive 
3  Branch must “turn square corners” before taking an action that profoundly disrupts the 
4  lives of hundreds of thousands of individuals, the Executive Branch once again acted 
5  recklessly and inexplicably to disrupt the lives of hundreds of thousands more. In 
6  March 2020, as the coronavirus public health emergency exploded, Immigration and 
7  Customs Enforcement (“ICE”), through its Student and Exchange Visitor Program 
8  (“SEVP”), issued Guidance documents (the “March Guidance”) assuring international 
9  students that, for “the duration of the [coronavirus] emergency,” they could continue 
10  their studies in the United States even if their colleges or universities were offering 
11  exclusively online classes due to the coronavirus pandemic. But then, on July 6, 
12  Defendants abruptly and without notice reversed course, and issued a new Guidance 
13  (the “July 6 Guidance”) requiring such students to leave the United States if, in light 
14  of the ongoing crisis, their schools continued with online-only instruction. After a 
15  public outcry and the filing of this action and others, Defendants announced their 
16  intent to rescind the July Guidance and subsequently issued new guidance allowing 
17  online-only instruction, but only for returning students and only for the fall 2020 
18  semester – not for the duration of the emergency should it extend for the remainder of 
19  the academic year. Plaintiffs continue to be at risk that Defendants may, at any time, 
20  reinstate the July 6 Guidance, thus necessitating Plaintiffs’ continued pursuit of this 
21  action.  
22  2.  The July 6 Guidance was a cruel and politically motivated directive that 
23  upended the lives of foreign students who are lawfully present in this country and who 
24  contribute immeasurably to the quality of education at the institutions they attend. 
25  These students chose to come to the United States to pursue degrees in law, medicine, 
26  engineering, and every other academic field. They wish to prepare themselves to lead 
27  productive lives that serve and build community wherever they ultimately settle.

1  Access to our outstanding institutions of higher education is one of the greatest gifts 
2  that the United States gives the world, and that gift is repaid many times over by the 
3  contributions that foreign students make to the United States and to the world as a 
4  whole by virtue of the learning they receive. Those contributions reflect their 
5  intelligence, compassion, and hard work. 
6  3.  In the midst of the most dangerous pandemic of the last hundred years, 
7  universities have reshaped their educational models to ensure the quality, continuity 
8  and safety of their educational programs. Utilizing their educational expertise and 
9  recognizing their paramount responsibility to the safety of the university community 
10  and the community at large, leadership at these schools have reluctantly accepted the 
11  judgments of our nation’s leading public health experts and CDC guidelines and have 
12  instituted remote learning and teaching strategies and regimens. It should go without 
13  saying that these decisions have not been easy. But it should also be readily 
14  recognized that a university’s decision to go all or principally remote is one of life and 
15  death. Universities are doing their part to flatten the curve and repel the deadly 
16  coronavirus that thrives on crowded settings inside buildings, precisely the 
17  circumstances of normal classroom teaching and university life. And until July 6, 
18  universities were doing so in reasonable reliance on guidance that ICE itself had 
19  provided in March 2020, and that promised a flexible approach of allowing students to 
20  maintain their visas while schools attempted, in good faith and with timely notice to 
21  ICE, to provide the best educational opportunities possible while fulfilling 
22  indispensable obligations to preserve the health of their students and their 
23  communities.    
24  4.  On July 6, ICE abruptly changed course 180 degrees, without explanation 
25  or even acknowledgement. Its decision sought to punish foreign students because their 
26  universities prioritized the health and safety of their academic and local communities 
27  and of the nation by choosing to hold remote classes beginning in the fall term.

1  5.  The July 6 Guidance offered no explanation whatsoever for the complete 
2  reversal in policy. But the facts are that the President of the United States, beset by 
3  falling poll numbers in a fast closing election year, has tweeted repeatedly that CDC 
4  guidelines must be altered and schools must open in the fall no matter the incongruity 
5  with fundamental public health principles and the sound, on-the-ground knowledge 
6  and expertise of university officials as to the safest course for their students and 
7  community. Indeed, on the day that the ICE message was issued, he tweeted that 
8  “SCHOOLS MUST OPEN IN THE FALL!!!”1 The next day, Acting Deputy 
9  Secretary of Homeland Security Ken Cuccinelli, responding to a question about the 
10  July 6 Guidance, explained the guidelines were “setting the rules . . . that will, again, 
11  encourage schools to reopen.”2 
12  6.  ICE’s announcement concerning international students attending 
13  institutions that did not offer in-person instruction, or who were not able to take the 
14  in-person classes that were offered, is part and parcel of the President’s approach. 
15  These guidelines, which adopted a one-size-fits-all approach to higher education, are 
16  blunt. They did not reflect the intensely local nature of university decisions, nor did 
17  they make exceptions for students at heightened risk from the novel coronavirus. 
18  Instead, the guidelines were designed to force institutions of higher education to 
19  reopen for the fall term, no matter the cost.  
20  7.  Institutions and students pushed back, and between July 8 and July 13 
21  filed over a half dozen lawsuits in 18 states challenging and seeking to invalidate the 
22  July 6 Guidance. Under pressure, Defendants again abruptly changed course and 
23  announced during a July 14 court hearing in the United States District Court for the 
24  District of Massachusetts that they would be rescinding and not implementing the July

11  of law, have everything.

3  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
4  23.  This Court has jurisdiction over this case pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1331 
5  and 5 U.S.C. § 702. Plaintiffs are persons aggrieved by a final agency action 
6  promulgated by Defendants. See 5 U.S.C. § 702. Plaintiffs bring this suit for 
7  declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside Defendants’ action as contrary to law and 
8  arbitrary and capricious, see id. §§ 705–706, and as a violation of due process under 
9  the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution—thus presenting a federal 
10  question, see 28 U.S.C. § 1331. 
11  24.  Venue is proper in this Court because Plaintiffs reside in this District—
12  specifically, a majority attend UCI and reside in or near Irvine—and no real property 
13  is involved. 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1)(C). 
14  25.  Plaintiffs have standing to bring this case. Defendants’ actions will cause 
15  an imminent, concrete, and irreparable risk of harm to Plaintiffs, their families, their 
16  educations, their short-term and long-term health, and their future education and 
17  employment prospects unless halted by this Court. 
18  26.  This Court is authorized to grant the requested injunctive relief pursuant 
19  to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65 and 5 U.S.C. § 705.

surrounded by shared surfaces - exactly the kind of prolonged exposure that creates 
21 
substantial risk of contracting the novel coronavirus. This is in addition to the added 
22 
risks associated with airports, whether it be standing in security lines or waiting at the 
23 
gate to board an aircraft.   
24 
89.  Such an itinerary is also exorbitantly, perhaps prohibitively, expensive. 
25 
As noted above, airfare may exceed $10,000 – especially given the need to book on 
26 
short notice. In addition, for students returning to countries, such as China, that have 
27

1  imposed a quarantine on incoming travelers, the students would have to pay for 14 
2  days’ lodging while they quarantine. 
3  90.  The financial and logistical challenges that Plaintiffs face multiply for 
4  international students with dependents. 
5  Health Risks 
6  91.  Forcing students to return to their countries of origin does more than put 
7  them at increased risk of exposure to the novel coronavirus during transit. In order to 
8  accommodate the course schedule and participate in extracurricular activities, 
9  plaintiffs, some of whom will not be given the option of asynchronous class 
10  participation, will be forced to maintain irregular sleep schedules.38 These sleep 
11  schedules will put students at a disadvantage compared to their peers, which poses a 
12  particular harm to plaintiff in classes that are graded on a curve. 
13  92.  Plaintiffs would also be burdened with health insurance costs. Many 
14  Plaintiffs have already paid for their 2020–21 health insurance plans through their 
15  university—plans that will do nothing for them in their country of origin. These 
16  Plaintiffs may need to buy health insurance in their home countries. Foregoing health 
17  insurance during the pandemic is not a realistic nor preferred option for Plaintiffs. 
18  However, given the costs associated with health insurance and the price of their now-
19  useless American insurance, Plaintiffs may go uncovered. 
20  Education Inequities 
21  93.  If Plaintiffs are forced to return to their home countries, it could be 
22  difficult or impossible for them to participate fully in classes and complete the 
23  academic year. Students in different time zones would be forced to choose between 
24  attending online classes in the middle of the night or watching recorded classes.39 
25

1  Students watching recordings will be harmed because they cannot ask questions 
2  during class, participate in class discussion, or otherwise have a visible presence. But 
3  students who attempt to participate as the class occurs must stay alert for two to three 
4  hours of lecture at inopportune times, often in the middle of the night. Either way, 
5  students will be put at a substantial disadvantage compared to their classmates taking 
6  the same class during normal hours. 
7  94.  Forcing Plaintiffs to return to their countries of origin will severely limit 
8  their practical learning opportunities. In law school, meeting and communicating with 
9  clients, supervisors, and team members constitute a large part of clinical experience. 
10  While any remote learning complicates these experiences, substantial time differences 
11  like those faced by Plaintiffs make them almost impossible. For example, students 
12  enrolled in legal clinical programs often have trouble scheduling meetings with clients 
13  even when the all reside in the same city; these meetings simply will not occur when 
14  the student attorney and the client must contend with a 16-hour difference. 
15  95.  The same applies to pro bono opportunities, many of which involve client 
16  intake interviews or group work. Limiting international students’ pro bono 
17  opportunities will disadvantage them, as some law schools confer graduation honors 
18  based on the number of pro bono hours completed.40 
19  96.  For some Plaintiffs, participating in online classes in their countries of 
20  origin may not be an option at all. Internet access, which is absolutely necessary for 
21  remote learning, is not guaranteed in some countries. Some countries have restricted 
22  internet access while others, like Ethiopia,41 block it altogether. Without adequate 
23  internet access, students cannot take online classes at all.

5  98.  China, for example, limits access to Google web products.42 Many 
6  schools, including UC Irvine, use Google products like Gmail and Google Drive to 
7  communicate and collaborate on academic and clinical assignments – and this is even 
8  more true now that teaching has moved online. If students cannot access these

10  Immigration Consequences 
11  99.  The July 6 Guidance prevented students whose schools will operate 
12  entirely online from applying for Curricular Practical Training and Optional Practical 
13  Training (“OPT”) visa programs. CPT allows international students to work in their 
14  field of study while they are enrolled in their academic program.44 OPT allows 
15  students to work in the United States for one year after graduation.45 To be eligible for 
16  OPT, students must have been enrolled in school full-time for one year, maintain valid 
17  F-1 status, and be physically present in the United States at the time of application.46  
18  Cancelling the F-1 visa or forcing international students to return to their countries of 
19  origin will make these students ineligible for CPT and will prevent them from

1  applying to OPT. No changes were made to the restrictions for CPT and OPT 
2  programs in the July 24 Guidance or August 7 Guidance.  
3  100.  Some international students have applied for permanent resident status, 
4  better known as the green card, and are waiting for approval. Plaintiffs are concerned 
5  that the new SEVP rule may extend the waiting time for students who must leave the 
6  United States because their schools will operate entirely online. 
7  Inequities in Employment Opportunities 
8  101.  Because of the risks associated with COVID-19, law schools across the 
9  nation have postponed to January their On-Campus Interviews (“OCI”), a yearly event 
10  where law firms travel to law school campuses to interview and recruit students for 
11  summer associate positions and eventual full-time employment. OCI is a competitive 
12  and important process for students. 
13  102.  If the July 24 Guidance is not extended beyond the fall 2020 semester (or 
14  if it is revoked during the fall semester), Plaintiffs will need to leave the country and 
15  will not be able to physically attend or fully participate in OCI.  
16  103.  If schools decide to hold virtual OCI, Plaintiffs have to interview in the 
17  middle of the night and compete against domestic students who are interviewing in 
18  normal business hours.  
19  104.  Furthermore, employers will easily be able to identify the immigration 
20  status of Plaintiffs. By simply asking about the time zone or city that Plaintiffs are in, 
21  employers can filter out international students among their interviewees. Due to the 
22  additional cost and precarious nature of sponsoring foreign nationals, some employers 
23  may avoid hiring international students for summer associate positions.47

CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
1 
Count 1: (Violation of Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §706) 
2 
Defendants’ Issue of the July 6 Guidance was Arbitrary and Capricious Both 
3 
Because It Failed Adequately to Consider the Reliance Interests of Millions of F-
4 
1 and M-1 Visa Holders and Because It Failed to Provide a Reasoned 
5  Explanation. 
6  105.  Plaintiffs incorporate the allegations contained in the preceding 
7  paragraphs. 
8  106.  The APA requires this Court to “hold unlawful and set aside agency 
9  action, findings, and conclusions found to be…arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of 
10  discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.” 5 U.S.C. §706(2)(A). Agency 
11  action must be the result of reasoned analysis. Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n of United 
12  States, Inc. v. State Farm Mu. Auto. Ins. Co., 463 U.S. 29, 57 (1983).  
13  107.  This standard applies even when an agency is altering existing guidance. 
14  When an agency changes course, the agency must “be cognizant that longstanding 
15  policies may have engendered serious reliance interests that must be taken into 
16  account.” Encino Motorcars LLC v. Navarro, 136 S. Ct. 2117, 2120 (2016). 
17  108.  As noted above, the United States has a long history of inviting 
18  international students to study as “non-immigrants” pursuant to a student visa 
19  program. International students admitted to well-established and high-quality 
20  institutions, such as those in the UC system, often have multiple options available to 
21  them. They choose to come study in the United States in reliance on the integrity of 
22  the visa program and the expectation that their student visas will remain valid as long 
23  as they are committed to their studies at their academic institutions. 
24  109.  The March 9 and March 13 guidance documents set forth a reasonable 
25  framework for addressing the implications of COVID-19 for F-1 and M-1 visas, as 
26  well as for updating the guidance in light of changes to the COVID-19 situation. The 
27  July 6 Guidance failed to identify any material changes to the COVID-19 situation 
  32 
28 
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 50   Filed 08/14/20   Page 33 of 39   Page ID #:408
 
1  that had occurred since March 13, and ignored entirely the approach and rationale 
2  underlying the March 9 and March 13 guidance documents.   
3  110.  The July 6 Guidance ignored the assurances Defendants have made to 
4  hundreds of thousands of students for well over twenty years that, as long as they 
5  remain in compliance with their academic programs, they will be able to remain in the 
6  United States at the institutions where they study.  
7  111.  The July 6 Guidance also ignored the reasonable reliance that students 
8  and schools alike placed in the approach to reconciling the impact of COVID-19 on F-
9  1 and M-1 visa requirements set forth in the March 9 and March 13 guidance 
10  documents.  
11  112.  The Supreme Court has recently emphasized that agencies modifying a 
12  previous policy are “required to assess whether there were reliance interests, 
13  determine whether they were significant, and weigh any such interests against 
14  competing policy concerns.” Department of Homeland Security v. Regents of Univ. of 
15  California 591 U.S. ___ (slip op., at 26) (2020). 
16  113.  The July 6 Guidance was arbitrary and capricious because it failed to 
17  consider these important reliance interests. Revoking international students’ visas 
18  when students have done everything in their power to remain in compliance with U.S. 
19  immigration law in the midst of a pandemic—and after Defendants announced at the 
20  outset of the pandemic that the United States would honor these visas during the 
21  pandemic despite the shift to online classes—disregarded the reliance interests of 
22  these students in maintaining their visa status and their ability to continue studying in 
23  the United States. The long history of the United States’ F-1 visa program, together 
24  with the March 13 Guidance, created a reasonable and justifiable expectation among 
25  students that they could maintain their visa status so long as they progressed in their 
26  particular course of study in whatever way that course of study was offered by their 
27  academic institution. 
  33 
28 
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 50   Filed 08/14/20   Page 34 of 39   Page ID #:409
 
1  114.  The reliance interests of F-1 visa holders extend further still. As 
2  discussed above, Plaintiffs have executed leases worth thousands of dollars for the 
3  upcoming school year. Many have paid for expensive health insurance plans that are 
4  now useless. Many will be forced to store or abandon property in the United States if 
5  they are required to exit the country on short notice or mid-way through the academic 
6  year. Many would not have paid tens of thousands of dollars in tuition to American 
7  universities had they known they could not be present in the country for the full 2020-
8  21 academic term. 
9  115.  This reliance was justifiably premised on Defendants’ March 9 and 
10  March 13 Guidance. For example, the March 13 Guidance advised F-1 Visa holders 
11  that the spring 2020 exemptions from online learning restrictions would exist “in 
12  effect for the duration of the emergency.”  
13  116.  Apart from the failure to address reliance interests, an agency’s failure to 
14  provide “reasoned analysis” for this sudden change in policy is “arbitrary, capricious, 
15  an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with the law.” 5 U.S.C. 
16  §706(2)(a). Here, the July 6 Guidance failed to offer any reasonable consideration of 
17  the painful consequences of the Guidance for students, schools, and communities. For 
18  example, the Guidance contain no discussion of the implications of this new policy for 
19  public health, of the status of the COVID-19 situation and how it was different in July 
20  than March in a way that was material for this guidance, or of how and why the 
21  guidance better served the purposes of the F-1 visa program, such as allowing 
22  “students to make normal forward progress in their studies,” than did the March 
23  guidance. The July 6 Guidance lacked even an acknowledgment of, let alone a 
24  justification for, the extraordinary human suffering it would have caused.   
25  117.  The Defendants’ voluntary and unexplained decision to change the July 6 
26  Guidance does not mean they can avoid adjudication of the APA violations because 
27  there are no procedural or other safeguards to ensure Defendants won’t arbitrarily 
  34 
28 
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 50   Filed 08/14/20   Page 35 of 39   Page ID #:410
 
1  revert to the July 6 Guidance, nor have Defendants provided a rationale for their 
2  changed practices that would ensure the arbitrary and capricious manner in which they 
3  sought to effect the forced removal of Plaintiffs and other international students 
4  through the July 6 Guidance will not happen again.    
5  118.  For these reasons and others, the July 6 Guidance must be declared to 
6  have been issued in a manner that was “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or 
7  otherwise not in accordance with law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A).  
8  Count II: (Violation of Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 553,706) 
9  The July 6 Guidance Violates the APA’s Notice-And-Comment Requirements. 
10  119.  Plaintiffs incorporate the allegations contained in the preceding 
11  paragraphs. 
12  120.  The APA requires this Court to hold unlawful and set aside any agency 
13  action taken “without observance of procedure required by law.” 5 U.S.C. 
14  § 706(2)(D). 
15  121.  The APA, 5 U.S.C. § 553, requires that any agency desiring to implement 
16  a rule go through the process of notice-and-comment in order to give the agency the 
17  benefit of the expertise of those most impacted by the potential rule-making. 
18  122.  The July Guidance did not go through any such process. Instead, DHS 
19  stated it planned to “publish the procedures and responsibilities in the Federal Register 
20  as a Temporary Final Rule.”48 
21  123.  The July 6 Guidance formalized a reversal of previous ICE guidance and 
22  thus is subject to notice and comment requirements. It is not an interpretive rule that 
23  could be issued without notice and comment requirements. Mt. Diablo Hospital Dist. 
24  v. Bowen, 860 F.2d 951, 956 (9th Cir. 1988).  
25 
26 
                                           
48 https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/sevp-modifies-temporary-exemptions-nonimmigrant-students-taking-online- 
27 
courses-during 
  35 
28

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 50   Filed 08/14/20   Page 36 of 39   Page ID #:411
 
1  124.  DHS has failed to provide any “good cause” that would justify bypassing 
2  the notice and comment period. 5 U.S.C. §553 (b)(3)(B). The good cause exception is 
3  only available to agencies if the agency has “good cause” to believe the process would 
4  be “impracticable, unnecessary, or contrary to the public interest.” Western Oil & Gas 
5  Ass’n v. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 633 F.2d 803, 810 (9th Cir. 1980). 
6  125.  The agency never “published reasons for thinking” the good cause 
7  applied to the rules in question. Id. 
8 
126.  DHS has failed to demonstrate how threatening to deport over one 
9 
million students in the middle of a global pandemic could possibly qualify as good 
10 
cause.  
11 
127.  The Defendants’ voluntary and unexplained decision to change the July 6 
12 
Guidance does not mean they can avoid adjudication of the APA violations because 
13 
there are no procedural or other safeguards to ensure Defendants won’t arbitrarily 
14 
revert to the July 6 Guidance, nor have Defendants provided a rationale for the 
15 
changed practices that would ensure the arbitrary and capricious manner in which 
16 
Defendants sought to effect the forced removal of Plaintiffs and other international 
17 
students through the July 6 Guidance will not happen again.    
18 
128.  By promulgating the July 6 Guidelines without notice and comment, ICE 
19 
violated 5 U.S.C. § 553 and § 706. The modifications it announced should be declared 
20 
unlawful.

Count III: (Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment) 
1   
The July 6 Guidance Deprive Plaintiffs of Their Visa Status 
2  Without Due Process of Law. 
3  129.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation 
4  contained in the preceding paragraphs. 
5  130.  Due process protections extend to “all ‘persons’ within the United States, 
6  including [non-citizens], whether their presence here is lawful, unlawful, temporary, 
7  or permanent.” Zadvydas v. Davis, 533 U.S. 678, 693 (2001). Nonimmigrant students 
8  are lawfully present in this country. 
9  131.  Nonimmigrant students have significant liberty and property interests, 
10  protected by the Due Process Clause, in their visas and/or access to educational 
11  programs to which they have been admitted and in which they have invested time, 
12  energy, and money. The “very essence” of due process is the “protection of the 
13  individual against arbitrary action.” Board of Regents of State Colls. v. Roth, 408 U.S. 
14  564, 584 (1972). The July 6 Guidance was so arbitrary, both in substance and the 
15  manner in which it was implemented, that it threatened to unlawfully deprive 
16  Plaintiffs of their constitutionally protected liberty and property interests. 
17  132.  Defendants’ voluntary and unexplained decision to change the July 6 
18  Guidance does not mean they can avoid adjudication of the due process violations 
19  because there are no procedural or other safeguards to ensure Defendants will not 
20  arbitrarily revert to the July 6 Guidance, nor have Defendants provided a rationale for 
21  their changed practices that would ensure the July 6 policy will not be reinstated.  
22  133.  Provisions of the July 24 and August 7 Guidance that limit their 
23  applicability to the fall 2020 terms also threaten to deprive Plaintiffs of their due 
24  process rights as Defendants could again implement a policy without due process 
25  protections that would force students to leave the country if their classes are offered 
26  only online.  
27 
  37 
28

2  irreparable injury.

4

unlawful and unlawfully promulgated; 
7

enforcing the policy announced in July 6 Guidance, or promulgating it as a Final Rule;

10 
the SEVP program in accordance with the March Guidance throughout the academic 
11 
year and for the duration of the COVID-19 emergency, unless replaced by a legally-
12 
sufficient agency rule promulgated through appropriate procedures, including notice 
13 
and comment; 
14 
4.  An order requiring Defendants to modify the July 24 Guidance and 
15 
August 7 Guidance consistent with the foregoing;  
16 
5.  An order awarding Plaintiffs their costs and attorneys’ fees; and/or

6.  Any and all other such relief as the Court may deem appropriate.

COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 3 of 35   Page ID #:3
 
1 INTRODUCTION 
2 1.  Less than one month after the Supreme Court held that the Executive 
3 Branch must “turn square corners” before taking an action that profoundly disrupts the 
4 lives of hundreds of thousands of individuals, the Executive Branch has once again 
5 acted recklessly and inexplicably to disrupt the lives of hundreds of thousands more. 
6 On July 6, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”) issued a press release 
7 announcing that students at colleges and universities that are offering exclusively 
8 online classes in the fall 2020 academic term because of the coronavirus pandemic 
9 would be required to leave the United States. This politically motivated directive 
10 upended the lives of foreign students who are lawfully present in this country and who 
11 contribute immeasurably to the quality of education at the institutions they attend. 
12 These students chose to come to the United States to pursue degrees in law, medicine, 
13 engineering, and every other academic field. They wish to prepare themselves to lead 
14 productive lives that serve and build community wherever they ultimately settle. 
15 Access to our outstanding institutions of higher education is one of the greatest gifts 
16 that the United States gives the world, and that gift is repaid many times over by the 
17 contributions that foreign students make to the United States and to the world as a 
18 whole by virtue of the learning they receive. Those contributions reflect their 
19 intelligence, compassion, and hard work. 
20 2.  In the midst of the most dangerous pandemic of the last hundred years, 
21 universities and graduate schools have reshaped their educational models to ensure the 
22 quality, continuity and safety of their educational programs. Utilizing their educational 
23 expertise and recognizing their paramount responsibility to the safety of the university 
24 community and the community at large, leadership at these schools have reluctantly 
25 accepted the judgments of our nation’s leading public health experts and CDC 
26 guidelines and have instituted remote learning and teaching strategies and regimens. It 
27 should go without saying that these decisions have not been easy. But it should also be 
28
  3 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 4 of 35   Page ID #:4
 
1 readily recognized that a university’s decision to go all or principally remote is one of 
2 life and death. Universities are doing their part to flatten the curve and repel the 
3 deadly coronavirus that thrives on crowded settings inside buildings, precisely the 
4 circumstances of normal classroom teaching and university life. And until July 6, 
5 universities were doing so in reasonable reliance on guidance that ICE itself had 
6 provided in March 2020, and that promised a flexible approach of allowing students to 
7 maintain their visas while schools attempted, in good faith and with timely notice to 
8 ICE, to provide the best educational opportunities possible while fulfilling 
9 indispensable obligations to preserve the health of their students and their 
10 communities.    
11 3.  On July 6, ICE abruptly changed course 180 degrees, without explanation 
12 or even acknowledgement.  Its decision effectively punishes foreign students because 
13 their universities have prioritized the health and safety of their academic and local 
14 communities and of the nation by choosing to hold remote classes in the fall term. 
15 4.  The July 6 Guidelines offer no explanation whatsoever for the complete 
16 reversal in policy. But the facts are that the President of the United States, beset by 
17 falling poll numbers in a fast closing election year, has tweeted repeatedly that CDC 
18 guidelines must be altered and schools must open in the fall no matter the incongruity 
19 with fundamental public health principles and the sound, on-the-ground knowledge 
20 and expertise of university officials as to the safest course for their students and 
21 community. Indeed, on the day that the ICE message was issued, he tweeted that 
22 “SCHOOLS MUST OPEN IN THE FALL!!!”1 The next day, Acting Deputy 
23 Secretary of Homeland Security Ken Cuccinelli, responding to a question about the 
24 July 6 Guidelines, explained the guidelines were “setting the rules . . . that will, again, 
25 encourage schools to reopen.”2 
                                           
26
1 Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump), Twitter (July 6, 2020, 2:40 PM EDT), 
https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1280209946085339136?s=20. 
27 2 
Johe Bowden, Cuccinelli Says Rule Forcing International Students to Return Home Will 'Encourage Schools to 
Reopen', The Hill (July 7, 2020),  
28
  4 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 5 of 35   Page ID #:5
 
1 5.  ICE’s announcement concerning international students attending 
2 institutions that did not offer in-person instruction, or who were not able to take the 
3 in-person classes that were offered, is part and parcel of the President’s approach. 
4 These guidelines, which adopt a one-size-fits-all approach to higher education, are 
5 blunt. They do not reflect the intensely local nature of university decisions, nor do 
6 they make exceptions for students at heightened risk from the novel coronavirus. 
7 Instead, the guidelines are designed to force institutions of higher education to reopen 
8 for the fall term, no matter the cost.  
9 6.  This life-threatening action makes foreign students pawns in a political 
10 drama. Tragically, but unsurprisingly, ICE’s press release was not accompanied by 
11 any of the safeguards the APA requires to insure “reasoned decision making” and 
12 accountability: notice and comment, rational explanation for the attack on prudent and 
13 grounded university decision making, and careful examination of the reliance interests 
14 of the students who are suddenly confronted with life and death choices. The ICE 
15 announcement makes no sense except as an irrational and cruel action designed to 
16 advance objectives having nothing to do with public health, learning, and reasonable 
17 immigration policy. The policy is indefensible, and the absence of any record or 
18 explanation for its sudden imposition is not just proof of illegality – it is evidence that 
19 no rational explanation exists.  
20 7.  The narratives of plaintiffs, all serious students pursuing meaningful 
21 careers, illustrate the irrationality of the ICE announcement and describe the terrible 
22 consequences of allowing it to take effect. Students required to come to campus and 
23 expose themselves to the coronavirus cannot do so without risking both their health 
24 and the health of others. Some students have preexisting conditions that heighten the 
25 danger. But if they act in keeping with essential public health practices, maintaining 
26 social distancing measures in enclosed spaces with strangers, they will be left asunder, 
27
                                           
https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/506248-cuccinelli-says-rule-forcing-international-students-to-return-home. 
28
  5 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 6 of 35   Page ID #:6
 
1 many with literally no place to go because of international travel restrictions to their 
2 home nations. They will jeopardize their immigration status and future education and 
3 career prospects. Their education will come to a screeching halt. They will be placed 
4 in financial calamity. 
5 8.  This lawsuit seeks the invalidation of the ICE guidelines upon the 
6 bedrock principles underlying the APA: reasoned decision making, public notice and 
7 hearing, and sensitive consideration of reasonable reliance interests. The government 
8 has nothing to lose by giving orderly respect to these mandates; the foreign students, 
9 their universities and communities, and those who stand by the rule of law, have 
10 everything. 
11 PARTIES 
12 9.  Plaintiff Z.W. is a 25 year-old Chinese national entering his second year 
13 of study at University of California Irvine School of Law in Irvine, California. After 
14 learning about UCI Law’s remote learning transition, he entered into a 13-month lease 
15 for an apartment in Irvine with monthly rent of $1,730 and security deposit. He 
16 entered into the lease with the expectation that he would be able to continue his 
17 education through distanced, remote learning. Z.W. was preparing to apply for a CPT 
18 visa so he could intern over the next, 2L summer to further his legal education.  His 
19 eligibility for the CPT visa, however, will be foreclosed if his F-1 visa is terminated.  
20 Similar to all plaintiffs who are Chinese nationals, he is deeply concerned with the 
21 financial costs associated with returning to China. He has paid a deposit for his 
22 apartment out of pocket, and does not know how he will manage to pay for a return 
23 flight to China, or the associated costs of China’s mandatory 14-day quarantine. His 
24 education will also be essentially prematurely terminated or paused, because of 
25 China’s prohibition on Google and VPN use, in addition to the 12 hour time 
26 difference.  
27
28
  6 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 7 of 35   Page ID #:7
 
1 10.  Plaintiff C.Y. is a 27 year-old Chinese national entering her second year 
2 of law school at UCI Law. She currently lives in Irvine, California where she moved 
3 in 2019 to enroll in her first year of law school. When UCI Law switched to online 
4 classes in March 2020 and SEVP issued the March 13 Guidance, C.Y. believed she 
5 would be able to continue her studies in the United States regardless of how UCI Law 
6 choose to offer classes in the fall. So she leased on-campus housing through spring 
7 2021, and pre-paid rent at a total cost of $10,380. If she were to have to return to 
8 China, she would not be able to recover that rent. Additionally, it would be 
9 prohibitively expensive for C. Y. to return to China, as the price of airline ticket from 
10 Los Angeles to China has increased several fold since the start of the pandemic and 
11 could easily exceed $10,000. Her family cannot afford to pay the price of her plan 
12 ticket back to China, nor can she. It will also be cost-prohibitive to pay for the hotel 
13 room in which she would be required to self-quarantine for 14 days after returning to 
14 China. If she were forced to return to China in the coming months, C. Y. also fears she 
15 will be exposed to the novel coronavirus on the flight to China and become infected, 
16 as she heard happened to more than a dozen people on a recent international flight to 
17 China. Once in China, C. Y. would not be able to continue to take law school classes 
18 due to, among other things, the unavailability in China of tools that UCI Law uses to 
19 facilitate online learning, including Google products (e.g., Google Drive) and secure 
20 VPNs. Additionally, the 15 to 16 hour time change would make it practically 
21 impossible for her to engage in clinical programs in which she has enrolled and to 
22 engage in important conferences with fellow students and professors. C. Y. does not 
23 feel safe attending in-person classes due to the health risks and therefore planned to 
24 take all of her courses online in the fall. The prospect of making C. Y. choose between 
25 a potentially unsafe in-person class and a prohibitively costly emergency journey 
26 home is causing her severe distress, which she will worries will negatively impact her 
27 grades. 
28
  7 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 8 of 35   Page ID #:8
 
1 11.  Plaintiff X. Y. is a 25-year-old Chinese national who has attended UCI 
2 Law on an F-1 visa since 2018 and this fall, will be entering her third and final year at 
3 UCI Law. In reliance upon the SVEP’s March guidance and UCI’s June statements 
4 that the fall semester would be held remotely, X.Y. and her partner, a UCLA student, 
5 entered into a 12-month lease for an apartment in Los Angeles. She also cancelled an 
6 August trip to visit family at home in China because she anticipated complications, 
7 including travel difficulties and the possibility of not being able to return to the United 
8 States to finish her program, resulting from the pandemic. She thought it was safer to 
9 stay in place. X. Y. is deeply concerned about the prospect of travel at a time of 
10 increased risk of community transmission both nationally in the United States and 
11 locally in Los Angeles. Her healthcare plan is effective through UCI enrollment, so 
12 she doesn’t know if she would have healthcare coverage in China. X. Y. is concerned 
13 she will have to drop out of school if she is forced to return to China, because 
14 attending live-streamed classes would mean that X. Y. would need to attend school in 
15 the middle of the night, and she would have no way to obtain required casebooks. X. 
16 Y. had planned to work as a research assistant for a professor during the upcoming 
17 semester, but it will be impossible to do so if she is in China. Her ability to apply for a 
18 permanent work visa, after being forced to return to China, will be considerably more 
19 burdensome than if she remained in the United States, as she had planned.   
20 12.  Plaintiff A. G. is a 25-year-old German national who has been attending 
21 the University of Southern California Law School (USC Law) in Los Angeles, 
22 California, on an F-1 visa, will be entering her third and final year. She lives in Los 
23 Angeles, where she is responsible for a lease and is employed through the summer by 
24 a law firm. Her responsibilities in the United States include being the sole familial 
25 caretaker for her almost 90 year-old great aunt who lives in Los Angeles. A. G. drives 
26 her to doctor’s appointments and goes grocery shopping for her. A. G. is nervous 
27 about the prospect of having to fly if she were forced to return to Germany, where she 
28
  8 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 9 of 35   Page ID #:9
 
1 would need to live with her immediate family. She fears that the return flight will 
2 expose her to the novel coronavirus and then put her family members at risk because 
3 of their high risk for COVID-19 complications. Her father has four stents in his heart 
4 and her mother has high blood pressure. She herself has no known pre-existing 
5 conditions, but she would be unable to take advantage of her US health insurance in 
6 Germany. If forced to return to Germany, A. G. would have difficulties continuing her 
7 studies, as she would need to take her classes in the middle of the night, due to the 
8 nine-hour time difference, and textbooks may be difficult to obtain. If USC Law were 
9 to transition to hybrid instruction, A. G. would attend in-person classes in order to stay 
10 in the country, but would not feel safe doing so. 
11 13.  Plaintiff M. X. is a 26-year-old Chinese national entering her second year 
12 of study at UCI Law. Because of the exemption granted by ICE, and UCI’s June 
13 announcement of remote instruction in the fall, M. X. decided to plan for the 
14 upcoming year by renewing her on-campus lease for a year, and has already begun 
15 paying rent under the lease. M. X. planned to continue her studies in the United States, 
16 and planned to intern next summer. In order to do so, she would need the CPT visa. 
17 Her eligibility for the CPT visa, however, will be foreclosed if her F-1 visa is 
18 terminated. She faces the additional financial burden of extremely expensive return 
19 flights to China and expenses associated with China’s mandatory 14-day quarantine. 
20 M. X. does not have the financial means to pay these required costs out of pocket on 
21 such short notice. Similarly, it would be effectively impossible for her to continue her 
22 studies while in China, due to the time difference and restrictions against Google and 
23 VPN use, meaning she would not be able to attend or participate in school even if the 
24 time zone were not an issue. If UCI were to transition to hybrid learning solely for 
25 international students, M. X. is concerned about the risk of infection in a classroom 
26 requiring physical attendance. 
27
28
  9 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 10 of 35   Page ID #:10
 
1 14.  Plaintiff Z. L. is a 25 year-old Chinese national who lives in Los Angeles 
2 and is enrolled as a PhD student at University of California, Los Angeles (“UCLA”), 
3 focusing on cinema and media studies. She enrolled at UCLA in 2017 and holds an F-
4 1 visa. After UCLA switched to online operations in late March, Z. L. remained in the 
5 United States because she did not want to risk her or her parents’ health and safety by 
6 traveling to China during a pandemic. She worries about returning to China because 
7 traveling will place her at risk of contracting COVID-19, as she will be exposed to 
8 people who may be infected with the virus at airports and inside the plane.  If she were 
9 forced to return to China, Z. L. would not be able to continue her studies for several 
10 reasons.  For instance, due to the 15-hour time difference between Los Angeles and 
11 China, Z. L. will have to attend her online classes at unconventional times. For 
12 example, Z. L. will have to call into a 1 p.m. Monday class at 4 a.m. on Tuesday, 
13 Beijing time.  Watching recorded classes is not an option for her because graduate-
14 level courses are designed to be centered around conversations and dialogue with 
15 other students than lecture. Relying on class recordings would deprive her of 
16 important opportunities to learn from and with her peers.  Z. L. is concerned that 
17 taking in-person classes will jeopardize her health, and had been planning to take all 
18 of her fall 2020 courses online.  In China, Z. L. will not be able to access the print and 
19 digital media resources she needs to complete her dissertation, and strict quarantine 
20 requirements will likely impair her ability to study for her PhD qualifying exam.  
21 Failure of the exam could jeopardize the funding she needs to complete the years-long 
22 program she has undertaken.  Z. L. housing situation is unsettled and if she returns to 
23 China she will have to pay costs of storage for her belongings and car.  Not knowing 
24 whether she must leave the country or risk serious illness—or even death—is keeping 
25 Z. L. tense and causing her great distress. 
26 15.  Plaintiff W. R. is a 26-year-old Chinese national entering his second year 
27 of school at UCI Law School who currently lives near Irvine, California in San Juan 
28
  10 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 11 of 35   Page ID #:11
 
1 Capistrano. Several months ago in March, UCI Law announced its decision to conduct 
2 remote instruction. Around that same time, W.R. received an exemption from ICE to 
3 remain in the United States with his wife, who is a permanent resident alien living in 
4 San Juan Capistrano and owns a business in the United States. If he is forced to return 
5 to China, he will be separated from his wife. He will also suffer financial losses based 
6 on decisions made in reliance on his ability to stay in the United States for his studies. 
7 If he is required to return to China, W. R.’s financial burden will also be compounded 
8 by the high cost of travel to China in the era of COVID-19, with average one-way 
9 economy flights priced at close to $10,000 (more than eight times the cost of a single 
10 flight to China before the pandemic). Additionally, passengers arriving from outside 
11 China are financially responsible for room and board associated with China’s 
12 mandatory 14-day quarantine, which would also be a financial hardship for W. R. If 
13 he is required to return to China, W. R.’s legal education will not be able to continue 
14 for all practical purposes. He will not be able to participate in classes, important 
15 group, or conduct necessary research due to the 15 to 16 hour time zone difference 
16 and China’s strict ban against Google and VPN usage, both of which are required to 
17 access the research databases and at UCI Law.  W. R. will also be unable to benefit 
18 from the student legal clinic in which he is enrolled for the upcoming fall semester if 
19 he has to return to China.  If he is required to attend in-person instruction, W. R. is 
20 concerned for his health and safety due to threat of exposure to the novel coronavirus. 
21 16.  Defendant United States Department of Homeland Security is a federal 
22 agency of the United States. 
23 17.  Defendant United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement is a 
24 division of the United States Department of Homeland Security. 
25 18.  Defendant Chad F. Wolf is the Acting Secretary of the United States 
26 Department of Homeland Security. He is sued in his official capacity. 
27
28
  11 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 12 of 35   Page ID #:12
 
1 19.  Defendant Matthew Albence is the Acting Director of the United States 
2 Immigration and Customs Enforcement. He is sued in his official capacity.  
3 JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
4 20.  This Court has jurisdiction over this case pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1331 
5 and 5 U.S.C. § 702. Plaintiffs are persons aggrieved by a final agency action 
6 promulgated by Defendants. See 5 U.S.C. § 702. Plaintiffs bring this suit for 
7 declaratory and injunctive relief to set aside Defendants’ action as contrary to law and 
8 arbitrary and capricious, see id. §§ 705–706, and as a violation of due process under 
9 the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution—thus presenting a federal 
10 question, see 28 U.S.C. § 1331. 
11 21.  Venue is proper in this Court because Plaintiffs reside in this District—
12 specifically, a majority attend UCI and reside in or near Irvine—and no real property 
13 is involved. 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1)(C). 
14 22.  Plaintiffs have standing to bring this case. Defendants’ actions will cause 
15 an imminent, concrete, and irreparable risk of harm to Plaintiffs, their families, their 
16 educations, their short-term and long-term health, and their future education and 
17 employment prospects unless halted by this Court. 
18 23.  This Court is authorized to grant the requested injunctive relief pursuant 
19 to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65 and 5 U.S.C. § 705. 
20 FACTS 
21 Higher Education and the COVID-19 Pandemic

25 and expose themselves to other travelers in order to return to the United States. 
26 88.  The financial and logistical challenges that Plaintiffs face multiply for 
27 international students with dependents.

Health Risks 
1
89.  Forcing students to return to their countries of origin does more than put 
2
them at increased risk of exposure to the novel coronavirus during transit. In order to 
3
accommodate the course schedule and participate in extracurricular activities, 
4
plaintiffs, some of whom will not be given the option of asynchronous class 
5
participation, will be forced to maintain irregular sleep schedules.43 These sleep 
6
schedules will put students at a disadvantage compared to their peers, which poses a 
7
particular harm to plaintiff in classes that are graded on a curve. 
8
90.  Plaintiffs are also burdened with health insurance costs. Many plaintiffs 
9
have already paid for their 2020–2021 health insurance plans through their 
10
university—plans that will do nothing for them in their country of origin. These 
11
plaintiffs may need to buy health insurance in their home countries. Foregoing health 
12
insurance during the pandemic is not a realistic nor preferred option for plaintiffs. 
13
However, given the costs associated with health insurance and the price of their now-
14
useless American insurance, plaintiffs may go uncovered. 
15
 
16
Education Inequities 
17
91.  The July 6 Guidelines make it difficult or impossible for plaintiffs to 
18
participate fully in class. Students in different time zones are forced to choose between 
19
attending online classes in the middle of the night or watching recorded classes.44 
20
Students watching recordings will be harmed because they cannot ask questions 
21
during class, participate in class discussion, or otherwise have a visible presence. But 
22
students who attempt to participate as the class occurs must stay alert for two to three 
23
hours of lecture at inopportune times, often in the middle of the night. Either way,

3 92.  Forcing plaintiffs to return to their countries of origin will severely limit 
4 their practical learning opportunities. In law school, meeting and communicating with 
5 clients, supervisors, and team members constitute a large part of clinical experience. 
6 While any remote learning complicates these experiences, substantial time differences 
7 like those faced by plaintiffs make them almost impossible. For example, many 
8 clinical students have trouble scheduling meetings with clients who lack access to

14 number of pro bono hours completed.45 
15 94.  For some plaintiffs, participating in online classes in their countries of 
16 origin may not be an option at all. Internet access, which is absolutely necessary for 
17 remote learning, is not guaranteed in some countries. Some countries have restricted 
18 internet access while others, like Ethiopia,46 block it altogether. Without adequate 
19 internet access, students cannot take online classes at all. 
20 95.  Other countries heavily monitor internet activity and curtail access to 
21 some resources. Beyond potentially exposing students to government harassment 
22 because of the contents of their studies, these restrictions will make it difficult or 
23 impossible for students in these countries to continue their studies.

1 96.  China, for example, limits access to Google web products.47 Many 
2 schools, including UC Irvine, use Google products like Gmail and Google Drive to 
3 communicate and collaborate on academic and clinical assignments – and this is even 
4 more true now that teaching has moved online. If students cannot access these 
5 resources, they will be locked out of their education.48  
6 Immigration Consequences 
7 97.  The July 6 Guidelines prevents students whose schools will operate 
8 entirely online from applying for Curricular Practical Training (“CPT”) and Optional 
9 Practical Training (“OPT”) visa programs. CPT allows international students to work 
10 in their field of study while they are enrolled in their academic program.49 OPT allows 
11 students to work in the United States for one year after graduation.50 To be eligible for 
12 OPT, students must have been enrolled in school full-time for one year, maintain valid 
13 F-1 status, and be physically present in the United States at the time of application.51 
14 Cancelling the F-1 visa or forcing international students to return to their countries of 
15 origin will make these students ineligible for CPT and will prevent them from 
16 applying to OPT. 
17 98.  Some international students have applied for permanent resident status, 
18 better known as the green card, and are waiting for approval. Plaintiffs are concerned 
19 that the new SEVP rule may extend the waiting time for students who must leave the 
20 United States because their schools will operate entirely online.

Inequities in Employment Opportunities 
1
99.  Because of the risks associated with COVID-19, law schools across the 
2
nation have postponed to January their On-Campus Interviews (OCI), a yearly event 
3
where law firms travel to law school campuses to interview and recruit students for 
4
summer associate positions and eventual full-time employment. OCI is a competitive 
5
and important process for students. 
6
100.  The July 6 Guidelines, however, deny plaintiffs the opportunity to 
7
physically attend OCI or fully participate in OCI. If schools hold OCI in person, 
8
Plaintiffs are practically blocked from participating because Plaintiffs will be required 
9
to find flights, find housing, self-quarantine, and ensure that they are free from 
10
COVID-19—if they are eligible to enter the United States at all. 
11
101.  If schools decide to hold virtual OCI, plaintiffs have to interview in the 
12
middle of the night and compete against domestic students who are interviewing in

normal business hours.  
14
102.  Furthermore, employers will easily be able to identify the immigration 
15
status of plaintiffs. By simply asking about the time zone or city that plaintiffs are in,

CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
20
Count 1: (Violation of Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §706) 
21
The July 6 Guidelines are Arbitrary and Capricious Both Because They Fail to 
22
Adequately Consider the Reliance Interests of Millions of F-1 and M-1 Visa 
23
Holders and Because They Fail to Provide a Reasoned Explanation. 
24
103.  Plaintiffs incorporate the allegations contained in the preceding 
25
paragraphs.

27

COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 30 of 35   Page ID #:30
 
1 104.  The APA requires this Court to “hold unlawful and set aside agency 
2 action, findings, and conclusions found to be…arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of 
3 discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.” 5 U.S.C. §706(2)(A). Agency 
4 action must be the result of reasoned analysis. Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n of United 
5 States, Inc. v. State Farm Mu. Auto. Ins. Co., 463 U.S. 29, 57 (1983).  
6 105.  This standard applies even when an agency is altering existing guidance. 
7 When an agency changes course, the agency must “be cognizant that longstanding 
8 policies may have engendered serious reliance interests that must be taken into 
9 account.” Encino Motorcars LLC v. Navarro, 136 S. Ct. 2117, 2120 (2016). 
10 106.  As noted above, the United States has a long history of inviting 
11 international students to study as “non-immigrants” pursuant to a student visa 
12 program. International students admitted to well-established and high-quality 
13 institutions, such as those in the UC system, often have multiple options available to 
14 them. They choose to come study in the United States in reliance on the integrity of 
15 the visa program and the expectation that their student visas will remain valid as long 
16 as they are committed to their studies at their academic institutions. 
17 107.  The March 9 and March 13 guidance documents set forth a reasonable 
18 framework for addressing the implications of COVID-19 for F-1 and M-1 visas, as 
19 well as for updating the guidance in light of changes to the COVID-19 situation.  The 
20 July 6 Guidelines identify no material changes to the COVID-19 situation since 
21 March 13, and ignore entirely the approach and rationale underlying the March 9 and 
22 March 13 guidance documents.   
23 108.  The July 6 Guidelines ignores the assurances SEVP has made to 
24 hundreds of thousands of students for well over twenty years that, as long as they 
25 remain in compliance with their academic programs, they will be able to remain in the 
26 United States at the institutions where they study.  
27
28
  30 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 31 of 35   Page ID #:31
 
1 109.  The July 6 Guidelines also ignore the reasonable reliance that students 
2 and schools alike placed in the approach to reconciling the impact of COVID-19 on F-
3 1 and M-1 visa requirements set forth in the March 9 and March 13 guidance 
4 documents.  
5 110.  The Supreme Court has recently emphasized that agencies modifying a 
6 previous policy are “required to assess whether there were reliance interests, 
7 determine whether they were significant, and weigh any such interests against 
8 competing policy concerns.” Department of Homeland Security v. Regents of Univ. of 
9 California 591 U.S. ___ (slip op., at 26) (2020). 
10 111.  The July 6 Guidelines are arbitrary and capricious because they fail to 
11 consider these important reliance interests. Revoking international students’ visas 
12 when the students have done everything in their power to remain in compliance with 
13 U.S. immigration law in the midst of a pandemic—and after SEVP announced at the 
14 outset of the pandemic that the United States would honor these visas during the 
15 pandemic despite the shift to online classes—disregards the reliance interests of these 
16 students in maintaining their visa status and their ability to continue studying in the 
17 United States. The long history of the United States’ F-1 visa program, together with 
18 the SEVP’s March 13 announcement, created a reasonable and justifiable expectation 
19 among students that they could maintain their visa status so long as they progressed in 
20 their particular course of study in whatever way that course of study was offered by 
21 their academic institution. 
22 112.  The reliance interests of F-1 visa holders extend further still.  As 
23 discussed above, plaintiffs have executed leases worth thousands of dollars for the 
24 upcoming school year. Many have paid for expensive health insurance plans that are 
25 now useless. Many will be forced to store or abandon property in the United States if 
26 they are required to exit the country on short notice. Many would not have paid tens of 
27
28
  31 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 32 of 35   Page ID #:32
 
1 thousands of dollars in tuition to American universities had they known they could not 
2 be present in the country for the fall term. 
3 113.  This reliance was justifiably premised on SEVP’s March 9 and March 13 
4 guidance. For example, the March 13 guidance advised F-1 Visa holders that the 
5 spring 2020 exemptions from online learning restrictions would exist “in effect for the 
6 duration of the emergency.”  
7 114.  Apart from the failure to address reliance interests, an agency’s failure to 
8 provide “reasoned analysis” for this sudden change in policy is “arbitrary, capricious, 
9 an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with the law.” 5 U.S.C. 
10 §706(2)(a). Here, the July 6 Guidelines fail to offer any reasonable consideration of 
11 the painful consequences of the Guidelines for students, schools, and communities. 
12 For example, the Guidelines contain no discussion of the implications of this new 
13 policy for public health, of the status of the COVID-19 situation and how it is 
14 different now than it was in March in a way that is material for this guidance, or of 
15 how and why this guidance better serves the purposes of the F-1 visa program, such as 
16 allowing “students to make normal forward progress in their studies,” than does the 
17 prior guidance.  The Guidelines lack even an acknowledgment of, let alone a 
18 justification for, the extraordinary human suffering they will cause.       
19 115.  For these reasons and others, the July 6 Guidelines must be vacated and 
20 “set aside” as “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in 
21 accordance with law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A).  
22 Count II: (Violation of Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 553,706) 
23 The July 6 Guidelines Violates the APA’s Notice-And-Comment Requirements. 
24 116.  Plaintiffs incorporate the allegations contained in the preceding 
25 paragraphs. 
26
27
28
  32 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 33 of 35   Page ID #:33
 
1 117.  The APA requires this Court to hold unlawful and set aside any agency 
2 action taken “without observance of procedure required by law.” 5 U.S.C. 
3 § 706(2)(D). 
4 118.  The APA, 5 U.S.C. § 553, requires that any agency desiring to implement 
5 a rule go through the process of notice-and-comment in order to give the agency the 
6 benefit of the expertise of those most impacted by the potential rule-making. 
7 119.  The July Guidelines did not go through any such process. Instead, DHS 
8 plans to “publish the procedures and responsibilities in the Federal Register as a 
9 Temporary Final Rule.”53 
10 120.  The July 6 Guidelines formalize a reversal of previous ICE guidance and 
11 thus is subject to notice and comment requirements. They are not an interpretive rule 
12 that could be issued without notice and comment requirements. Mt. Diablo Hospital 
13 Dist. v. Bowen, 860 F.2d 951, 956 (9th Cir. 1988).  
14 121.  DHS has failed to provide any “good cause” that would justify bypassing 
15 the notice and comment period. 5 U.S.C. §553 (b)(3)(B) The good cause exception is 
16 only available to agencies if the agency has “good cause” to believe the process would 
17 be “impracticable, unnecessary, or contrary to the public interest.” Western Oil & Gas 
18 Ass’n v. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 633 F.2d 803, 810 (9th Cir. 1980). 
19 122.  The agency has yet to “publish[] reasons for thinking” the good cause 
20 applies to the rules in question. Id. 
21 123.  DHS has failed to demonstrate how threatening to deport over one 
22 million students in the middle of a global pandemic could possibly qualify as good 
23 cause.  
24 124.  By promulgating the July 6 Guidelines without notice and comment, ICE 
25 violated 5 U.S.C. § 553 and § 706. The modifications it announced are unlawful and 
26 must be vacated. 
                                           
27
53 https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/sevp-modifies-temporary-exemptions-nonimmigrant-students-taking-online- 
courses-during 
28
  33 
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220   Document 1   Filed 07/10/20   Page 34 of 35   Page ID #:34
 
Count III: (Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment) 
1  
The July 6 Guidelines Deprive Plaintiffs of their Visa Status 
2 Without Due Process of Law. 
3 125.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation 
4 contained in the preceding paragraphs. 
5 126.  Due process protections extend to “all ‘persons’ within the United States, 
6 including [non-citizens], whether their presence here is lawful, unlawful, temporary, 
7 or permanent.” Zadvydasv. Davis, 533 U.S. 678, 693 (2001). Nonimmigrant students 
8 are lawfully present in this country. 
9 127.  Nonimmigrant students have significant liberty and property interests, 
10 protected by the Due Process Clause, in their visas and/or access to educational 
11 programs to which they have been admitted and in which they have invested time, 
12 energy, and money.  The “very essence” of due process is the “protection of the 
13 individual against arbitrary action.” Board of Regents of State Colls. v. Roth, 408 U.S. 
14 564, 584 (1972). The July 6 Guidelines are so arbitrary, both in substance and the 
15 manner in which they were implemented, that they unlawfully deprive Plaintiffs of 
16 their constitutionally protected liberty and property interests. 
17 128.  As a result of the foregoing constitutional violations, Plaintiffs will suffer 
18 irreparable injury. 
19 PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
20
Wherefore, Plaintiffs respectfully seek the following relief: 
21
1.  A declaration that the policy announced in the July 6 Guidelines is 
22
unlawful and unlawfully promulgated; 
23
2.  A temporary restraining order and preliminary and permanent injunctive 
24
relief preventing Defendants from enforcing the policy announced in July 6 
25
Guidelines, or promulgating it as a Final Rule; 
26
/ / / 
27
/ / / 
28
  34

1 3.  An order vacating and setting aside the policy announced in the July 6 
2 Guidelines and reinstating the March 13 Guidance; 
3 4.  An order awarding Plaintiffs their costs and attorneys’ fees; and 
4 5.  Any and all other such relief as the Court may deem appropriate.

1  APPLICATION 
2  Plaintiffs are law students or graduate students at University of California Irvine 
3  School of Law, University of California Los Angeles, and the University of Southern 
4  California, who are currently studying in the United States on F-1 visas as part of the 
5  Student and Exchange Visa Program (“SEVP”) administered by U.S. Immigration and 
6  Customs Enforcement under the authority of the Department of Homeland Security 
7  (collectively, “Defendants”). Each of Plaintiffs’ schools has announced that, due to the 
8  ongoing (and worsening) COVID-19 crisis, instruction for Plaintiffs’ fall semesters 
9  will be online only. 
10  Under Guidance issued by SEVP in March, Plaintiffs would be able to continue 
11  living and studying in the United States for the fall semester. But on July 6, 2020, 
12  Defendants abruptly announced a policy change: if a school proceeds with online-only 
13  instruction for the fall semester, then SEVP students “must leave the country or take 
14  alternative steps to maintain their nonimmigrant status such as transfer to a school 
15  with in-person instruction.” At this point, Plaintiffs have no feasible ability to transfer 
16  to a different school, and if forced to leave the United States would be subject to 
17  extreme financial hardship, health risks, and disruption to their courses of study.  
18  On July 10, 2020, Plaintiffs filed a complaint challenging the July 6 policy 
19  change on the following grounds: (1) it is “arbitrary and capricious” in the violation 
20  the APA because Defendants failed to consider stakeholders’ reliance interests on the 
21  prior policy, and because Defendants failed to provide a reasoned explanation; (2) it 
22  was improperly issued without meeting notice-and-comment requirements, also in 
23  violation of the APA; and (3) it violates the Due Process Clause. Plaintiffs now 
24  request a temporary restraining order (“TRO”) enjoining the implementation of the 
25  July 6 policy change on the grounds that Plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the merits, 
26  Plaintiffs will suffer irreparable harm absent emergency relief, and the balance of 
27  hardships and public interest tip sharply in favor of Plaintiffs and maintaining the 
28  status quo.

1  INTRODUCTION 
2  Plaintiffs are among the hundreds of thousands of international students who 
3  have come to the United States as part of the Student and Exchange Visa Program 
4  (“SEVP”), where they have invested time, money, and energy into pursuing their 
5  degrees. When the COVID-19 crisis hit, SEVP initially responded appropriately. On 
6  March 9, 2020, it issued a guidance assuring visa students that they could remain in 
7  the country, even if their universities went to online-only instruction.1 It further 
8  advised that the adapted procedures were “for the duration of the emergency.”2 
9  The COVID-19 emergency has not abated; to the contrary, COVID-19 cases are 
10  surging. Given these conditions, and in reliance on the March Guidance, numerous 
11  universities have already committed to online instruction for the fall, and students 
12  have also planned accordingly. Yet on July 6, Defendants abruptly shifted course: they 
13  announced that, if a school continues with online-only instruction for the fall semester, 
14  SEVP students “must leave the country or take alternate steps … such as transferring 
15  to a school with in-person instruction.”3  
16  Just one month ago, the Supreme Court warned that, when the Executive 
17  Branch changes course, it must “turn square corners” by considering all important 
18  aspects of the problem, including people’s reliance on the prior policy. Dep’t of 
19  Homeland Security v. Regents of Univ. of Cal., 140 S. Ct. 1891, 1909, 1914 (2020) ( 
20  “Regents”). Defendants again have failed to heed that requirement.  
21  The July 6 policy change is unsupported by any reasoned explanation and is 
22  entirely arbitrary, whether viewed from the perspective of public health, the integrity

6  schools to reopen”—which is the explanation for the policy given to reporters by

16  (3) quarantining. Id. ¶ 25.
