LEGAL STANDARD 
19  Motions for temporary restraining orders are governed by the same four-factor 
20  test as preliminary injunctions: Courts consider whether petitioners have shown: (1) a 
21  likelihood of success on the merits, (2) that they are likely to suffer irreparable harm 
22  in the absence of such relief, (3) that the balance of equities tips in their favor, and 
23  (4) that an injunction is in the public interest. Winter v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc., 
24  555 U.S. 7, 20 (2008); Hernandez v. Sessions, 872 F.3d 976, 989-90 (9th Cir. 2017).  
25  Under the Ninth Circuit’s “sliding scale” approach, “a stronger showing of one 
26  element may offset a weaker showing of another.” Hernandez, 872 F.3d at 989-90 
27  (quoting Pimentel v. Dreyfus, 670 F.3d 1096, 1105 (9th Cir. 2012) (per curiam)). For 
28 
  19 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 16   Filed 07/14/20   Page 22 of 35   Page ID #:132
 
1  example, injunctive relief is warranted when an applicant raises “serious questions 
2  going to the merits,” if the balance of hardships “tips sharply towards” granting an 
3  injunction in light of the danger of irreparable harm and after weighing the public 
4  interest. Disney Enters., Inc. v. VidAngel, Inc., 869 F.3d 848, 856 (9th Cir. 2017) 
5  (quoting All. for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell, 632 F.3d 1127, 1134-35 (9th Cir. 2011)). 
6  ARGUMENT 
7  I.  PLAINTIFFS ARE LIKELY TO SUCCEED ON THE MERITS 
8  As set forth in Plaintiffs’ Complaint and below, the July 6 Guidance violates the 
9  Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), 5 U.S.C. § 706, because it is arbitrary and 
10  capricious in failing to consider the reliance interests of student visa holders and 
11  failing to provide a reasoned explanation for the change in policy, notwithstanding the 
12  fact that the COVID-19 crisis is continuing and, indeed, surging. The July 6 Guidance 
13  was also issued without meeting notice-and-comment requirements for actions 
14  affecting substantial rights and is so arbitrarily imposed as to violate due process.  
15 
A.  The July 6 Policy Change Is Arbitrary and Capricious, in Violation 
of the APA. 
16 
The APA provides a mechanism for courts to review final agency action, 5 
17 
U.S.C. § 702, and it directs courts “[to] hold unlawful and set aside” actions that are 
18 
“arbitrary” or “capricious,” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). See Regents, 140 S. Ct. at 1905. At 
19 
its core, the APA requires agencies “to engage in ‘reasoned decisionmaking.’” Id. 
20 
(citation omitted). Agency action will be found arbitrary and capricious where the 
21 
agency has “‘failed to consider an important aspect of the problem.’” Id. at 1910 
22 
(quoting Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Assn. of United States, Inc. v. State Farm Mut. Auto. 
23 
Ins. Co., 463 U.S. 29, 43 (1983)); see also Amerijet Int’l, Inc. v. Pistole, 753 F.3d 
24 
1343, 1350 (D.C. Cir. 2014) (explaining that it is “a fundamental requirement of 
25 
administrative law … that an agency set forth its reasons for decision[s]; an agency’s 
26 
failure to do so constitutes arbitrary and capricious agency action”) (citation omitted).  
27 
Here, the July 6 policy change qualifies as final agency action under the APA.

19 
In Regents, the Supreme Court explained that when an agency changes policy in 
20 
a way that affects substantial interests, it must “turn square corners.” 140 S. Ct. at 
21 
1909 (internal quotation omitted). That includes considering “whether there was 
22 
‘legitimate reliance’” on the prior policy, even if the prior policy was merely an 
23 
exception to the enforcement of the law as written and did not purport to provide any 
24 
permanent rights. Id. at 1913. In other words, when an agency is “not writing on a 
25 
blank slate,” it is “required to assess whether there were reliance interests, determine 
26 
whether they were significant, and weigh any such interests against competing policy 
27 
concerns.” Id. at 1915 (emphasis added). The failure to do so, by itself, renders an

15 
The policy change violates the APA for a separate and independent reason. 
16 
When an agency is promulgating a new substantive rule, it must follow notice-and-
17 
comment ruling procedures. 5 U.S.C. §§ 551(4), 553. That includes (1) publication of 
18 
notice of the proposed rule in the Federal Register; (2) a period for interested 
19

not less than thirty days before its effective date.” 5 U.S.C. § 553(b), (c), (d) (2006); 
21 
Mora-Meraz v. Thomas, 601 F.3d 933, 939 (9th Cir. 2010). If a new substantive rule 
22 
is promulgated “without observance of procedure required by law,” then it must be set 
23 
aside. 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(D). 
24

substantive rule because it redefines what students must do “to maintain their F-1 and

for in-person instruction “to remain in lawful status” or else “face immigration

7  “Temporary Final Rule” would soon be published in the Federal Register, further 
8  confirming Defendants’ intent to engage in rulemaking changing the SEVP 
9  “procedures and responsibilities” during the COVID-19 crisis. Notably, however, 
10  there is no suggestion that Defendants intend to engage in any notice-and-comment 
11  period. To the contrary, and as noted above, the July 6 Guidance is clear that 
12  Defendants expect schools and students to comply with new rules now, with students 
13  otherwise being subject to removal proceedings.  
14  Had Defendants complied with the APA’s require procedures, they would have 
15  received comments from schools and students alike, reflecting how ill-conceived, 
16  unfair, and harmful the policy change is. Regardless, the procedural violation itself 
17  requires the Court to set the policy change aside. See Cedars-Sinai Med. Ctr. v. 
18  Shalala, 939 F. Supp. 1457 (C.D. Cal. 1996) (citing Linoz v. Heckler, 800 F.2d 871, 
19  878 (9th Cir. 1986)); 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(D). Accordingly, Defendants have shown a 
20  likelihood of success on this issue as well. 
21 
C.  The July 6 Guidance Violates Due Process 
22  Even apart from if the APA violation, the July 6 Guidance imposes an arbitrary 
23  and irrational deprivation of Plaintiffs’ constitutionally protected liberty and property 
24  interest, in violation of the Due Process Clause.  
25  “[T]he touchstone of due process is protection of the individual against arbitrary 
26  action of government, whether the fault lies in a denial of fundamental procedural 
27  fairness, or in the exercise of power without any reasonable justification in the service 
28 
  28 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 16   Filed 07/14/20   Page 31 of 35   Page ID #:141
 
1  of a legitimate governmental objective.” Cty. of Sacramento v. Lewis, 523 U.S. 833, 
2  845-46 (1998) (citations omitted). The Due Process Clause forbids the deprivation of 
3  “life, liberty, or property, without the due process of law,” and applies to all ‘persons’ 
4  within the United States, including noncitizens like Plaintiffs who are in the country. 
5  U.S. Constitution, Art. V; see Zadvyadas v. Davis, 533 U.S. 678, 693 (2001) (“[T]he 
6  Due Process Clause applies to all ‘persons’ within the United States ... whether their 
7  presence here is lawful, unlawful, temporary, or permanent.”). 
8  Here, Plaintiffs have complied with the rigorous SEVP requirements and have 
9  secured admission to highly competitive institutions while investing time, money, and 
10  energy into pursuing their degrees in this county. They have a cognizable liberty 
11  interest in not being arbitrarily subject to removal proceedings. See Chew v. Colding, 
12  344 U.S. 590 (1953). And they have a cognizable property interest in their visas and 
13  being able to continue the educational endeavors in which they have invested so 
14  heavily, in reliance on the integrity of the student-visa program and their ability to 
15  remain in the United States so as long as they remain committed to pursuing the full 
16  course of study offered by their SEVP-certified institutions. See Board of Regents of 
17  State Colleges v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 577 (1972) (it is the purpose of the institution of 
18  “property” to “protect those claims upon which people rely in their daily lives, 
19  reliance that must not be arbitrarily undermined.”). 
20  For all of the reasons explained above, the July 6 Guidance is so arbitrary and 
21  irrational as to violate due process’s protection of these constitutional interests. The 
22  July 6 Guidance is not rationally related to mitigating the spread of the coronavirus, 
23  because forcing students to attend in-person instruction will only increase the 
24  likelihood of transmission. Nor can the July 6 Guidance be justified as responding to 
25  changing conditions, because it was imposed notwithstanding the fact that the public 
26  health emergency continues. Finally, the date it was issued—after schools and 
27  students had already committed to their fall programs, and with no meaningful 
28  opportunity to make alternative arrangements—confirms the arbitrariness of 
  29 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 16   Filed 07/14/20   Page 32 of 35   Page ID #:142
 
1  Defendants’ actions, all in total disregard for Plaintiffs’ substantial and 
2  constitutionally protected interests. While courts use counsel and restraint when 
3  considering substantive due process claims, “history does not counsel abandonment” 
4  of all such claims particularly when, as here, government policies are so obviously 
5  arbitrary and serve no rational governmental interest.  See Moore v. City of East 
6  Cleveland Ohio, 431 U.S. 494, 502 (1977). Accordingly, Plaintiffs have established a 
7  likelihood of success on this claim as well. 
8 
II.  PLAINTIFFS WILL SUFFER IRREPARABLE HARM ABSENT 
EMERGENCY RELIEF.  
9 
Plaintiffs will suffer irreparable harm if the July 6 Guidance is allowed to stand.  
10 
There is no safe or realistic option for Plaintiffs to stay in the country to 
11 
complete their studies. Transferring to a school offering in person classes is not a 
12 
realistic possibility at this late stage, with deadlines fast approaching and with schools 
13 
already struggling to implement social distancing and online learning plans that will 
14 
protect the health and safety of their existing student body. See generally Zearfoss 
15 
Decl. In any event, attending in-person classes in the midst of a raging pandemic 
16 
would subject the Plaintiffs and the people around them –including high-risk family 
17 
members – to risk of infection with COVID-19. Mishori Decl. ¶ 25-34. Thus, as a 
18 
practical matter, if the July Guidance stands, Plaintiffs will be forced to leave the 
19 
country, incurring numerous harmful impacts on Plaintiffs. 
20 
For one, Plaintiffs cannot practically continue their education if they are forced 
21 
to leave the country. Several Plaintiffs have limited internet access and limits imposed 
22 
by the government of their home country on the computer tools that their schools use 
23 
to communicate and collaborate, preventing them from fully accessing the curriculum. 
24 
To the extent Plaintiff could access class remotely, the difference in time zones would 
25 
require them to attend classes in the middle of the night or lose the opportunity to 
26 
actively participate in class by attending recorded sessions. Plaintiffs also will be 
27 
severely limited in their opportunities to participate in clinics or pro bono work, which 
28 
  30 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 16   Filed 07/14/20   Page 33 of 35   Page ID #:143
 
1  impacts their academic standing. These limitations will disadvantage Plaintiffs with 
2  respect to job and training opportunities. See supra at Background Part D. 
3  Further, Plaintiffs will face extreme financial losses and hardship if they are 
4  forced to return to their home countries at this late stage. Plaintiffs have already 
5  signed leases and put down money on housing that would be lost; they would have to 
6  incur travel and moving expenses not only to move back to their home countries, but 
7  also to return to the U.S. if their schools return to in person classes. Plaintiffs who 
8  have purchased U.S. health insurance also would lose both the money they invested 
9  and the benefit of that insurance–in the midst of a global pandemic. See supra at 
10  Background Part D. 
11  Traveling back to their home countries may also be extremely difficult for 
12  certain Plaintiffs. Multiple countries have banned all transnational flights in response 
13  to the pandemic, and others—including China the home country of several 
14  Plaintiffs—require incoming travelers to quarantine at their own expense for two 
15  weeks upon arrival. Moreover, the travel itself would expose Plaintiffs to healthy 
16  risks, as lengthy transnational flights present multiple infection risks. See supra at 
17  Background Part D. 
18  Finally, Plaintiffs will suffer severe personal hardships if the July Guidance 
19  were allowed to stand, including separation from spouses, partners, family and 
20  friends. Plaintiffs have suffered and will continue to suffer stress and anxiety at the 
21  prospect of being deported, losing their expected educational and employment 
22  opportunities, and the detrimental and even devastating financial burden of being 
23  forced out of the country. See supra at Background Part D. 
24 
III.  THE BALANCE OF HARDSHIPS AND PUBLIC INTEREST TIP 
SHARPLY IN FAVOR OF EMERGENCY RELIEF. 
25 
The final factors in evaluating a TRO or preliminary injunction involve the 
26 
balance of hardships and public interest—factors that generally merge when the 
27 
Government is a party. See League of Wilderness Defenders v. Connaughton, 752 
28 
  31 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 16   Filed 07/14/20   Page 34 of 35   Page ID #:144
 
1  F.3d 755, 766 (9th Cir. 2014). Here, the balance of hardships and public interest tip 
2  sharply in favor of emergency relief.  
3  Plaintiffs are students whom the United States invited and encouraged to come 
4  here to study. They have invested time, money, and energy into their courses of study, 
5  and obviously would be attending classes in person, but for exceptional circumstances 
6  beyond their control. Defendants’ threat to deport them thrown their lives—and the 
7  lives of other international students—into complete disarray, impacting their 
8  educational pursuits, their financial well-being, and the health and safety of 
9  themselves, their families, and their communities.  
10  On the flip side, Defendants have not identified any material interest supporting 
11  the policy. Rather, the very point of the policy change is to impose severe hardship on 
12  international students to leverage schools into reopening. See Bowden, supra n.4. 
13  Even were that a valid government interest, it proves that the balance of hardships tips 
14  decisively in Plaintiffs’ favor. Moreover, the Government “cannot suffer harm from 
15  an injunction that merely ends an unlawful practice,” Rodriguez v. Robbins, 715 F.3d 
16  1127, 1145 (9th Cir. 2013), and the “public interest is served by compliance with the 
17  APA.” East Bay Sanctuary Covenant v. Trump, 950 F.3d 1242, 1280-81 (9th Cir. 
18  2020) (quoting  California v. Azar, 911 F.3d 558, 581 (9th Cir. 2018)). 
19 
CONCLUSION 
20  For the foregoing reasons, Plaintiffs respectfully request that the Court issue a 
21  TRO enjoining Defendants’ implementation of the July 6 Guidance. Such TRO should 
22  include requiring Defendants to issue a further broadcast message that the July 6  
   
23 
24 
25 
26 
27 
28 
  32 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 16   Filed 07/14/20   Page 35 of 35   Page ID #:145
 
1  policy change and any related compliance obligations have been enjoined, pending 
2  resolution on the merits.  
3

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 49   Filed 08/03/20   Page 1 of 2   Page ID #:374
 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
CIVIL MINUTES – GENERAL 
 
Case No. SACV 20-01220-CJC-KES  Date:  August 3, 2020 
 
Title: Z.W., ET AL. V. UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY, ET 
AL. 
 
 
 
PRESENT: 
 
HONORABLE CORMAC J. CARNEY, UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
 
  Gabriela Garcia                  N/A   
  Deputy Clerk            Court Reporter 
 
ATTORNEYS PRESENT FOR PLAINTIFF:     ATTORNEYS PRESENT FOR DEFENDANT: 
 
  None Present            None Present 
 
PROCEEDINGS: (IN CHAMBERS) ORDER DENYING PLAINTIFFS’ APPLICATION 
FOR TEMPORARY RESTRAINING ORDER [Dkt. 16] AND AMENDED 
APPLICATION FOR TEMPORARY RESTRAINING ORDER [Dkt. 36] AND DENYING 
WITHOUT PREJUDICE DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO DISMISS [Dkt. 45]  
 
On July 10, 2020, Plaintiffs—all of whom are graduate students studying at California 
universities on F-1 visas—brought this action seeking relief from the Guidance issued by the 
Department of Homeland Security’s Student and Exchange Visa Program (“SEVP”) on July 6, 
2020.  (Dkt. 1 [Complaint].)  The July 6 Guidance barred student visa holders from remaining in 
the United States during the upcoming fall semester if their universities cancelled in-person 
classes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.  Four days after filing suit, Plaintiffs applied for 
a temporary restraining order that would enjoin Defendants from implementing the July 6 
Guidance.  (Dkt. 16 [TRO Application, hereinafter “TRO”].)  Later that same day, however, 
Defendants rescinded the challenged Guidance.  (Dkt. 18.)  Defendants’ rescission of the July 6 
Guidance was finalized on July 24, 2020 when the United States Immigration and Customs 
Enforcement (“ICE”) issued updated guidance confirming that it will “abide by SEVP guidance 
originally issued in March 2020” which “enables schools and students to engage in distance 
learning in excess of regulatory limits due to the public health emergency generated by COVID-
19.”  (Dkt. 46-1 [July 24 Broadcast Message].) 
 
Now before the Court are Plaintiffs’ application for a temporary restraining order (TRO), 
Plaintiffs’ amended application for a temporary restraining order (Dkt. 36 [hereinafter “Amended 
TRO”].), and Defendants’ motion to dismiss, (Dkt. 45 [hereinafter “Mot.”].).  Plaintiffs concede 
 

Case 8:20-cv-01220-CJC-KES   Document 49   Filed 08/03/20   Page 2 of 2   Page ID #:375
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
CENTRAL DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
CIVIL MINUTES – GENERAL 
 
Case No. SACV 20-01220-CJC-KES  Date:  August 3, 2020 
                                                                                               Page 2  
 
that “a TRO is no longer necessary because the July 24 Guidance provides much of the relief 
sought in the TRO Application.”  (Dkt. 48 [Opposition to Motion to Dismiss] at 1.)  
Accordingly, both the original TRO application and the Amended TRO application are 
DENIED.   
 
In their motion to dismiss, Defendants contend the rescission of the July 6 Guidance 
moots this action in its entirety and that it should be dismissed altogether.  (See Mot.)  Plaintiffs 
oppose that motion and request leave to amend their Complaint so that they can clarify the relief 
they continue to seek.  (Id. at 3.)  The Court finds that such amendments are necessary so that the 
operative pleading aligns with the current state of affairs.  Accordingly, Defendants’ motion to 
dismiss is DENIED WITHOUT PREJUDICE.  Plaintiffs are hereby ORDERED to file an 
amended pleading that sets forth the relief they continue to seek by August 14, 2020.  The 
hearing on Defendants’ motion set for August 24, 2020 is hereby vacated and taken off calendar.
